pli-tv-bu-pm:0.2: The Code of Conduct for Theravada Monks
pli-tv-bu-pm:1.2: these are called “preparations” for the Uposatha.
pli-tv-bu-pm:2.1: Consent, purity, telling the season, counting the monks, and the exhortation:
pli-tv-bu-pm:2.2: these are called the “preliminary duties” for the Uposatha.
pli-tv-bu-pm:3.1: The Uposatha has arrived; all monks in the stated boundary are present;
pli-tv-bu-pm:3.3: and no legally indicted monk is present: these are called “factors of readiness”.
pli-tv-bu-pm:4.1: Having completed the preparations and the preliminary duties, with the agreement of the assembled monks who have confessed any offences, I invite the commencement of the recitation of the Code of Conduct.
pli-tv-bu-pm:5.1: “Sir, let the Saṅgha listen to me.
pli-tv-bu-pm:5.2: Today is the Uposatha on the fifteenth day.
pli-tv-bu-pm:5.3: If the Sangha is ready, let the Sangha perform the Uposatha and recite the Code of Conduct.
pli-tv-bu-pm:6.1: What is the Sangha’s preliminary duty?
pli-tv-bu-pm:6.2: Let the venerables announce their purity,
pli-tv-bu-pm:6.3: I shall recite the Code of Conduct.
pli-tv-bu-pm:6.4: All those present must listen well and pay attention.
pli-tv-bu-pm:6.5: Whoever has an offence must declare it,
pli-tv-bu-pm:6.6: but if there is no offence remain silent.
pli-tv-bu-pm:6.7: By their silence I shall understand that the Venerables are pure.
pli-tv-bu-pm:6.8: If a person were to be individually questioned they would have to answer. In just the same way, one is informed three times in an assembly such as this.
